page.title: 18LANDSCAPE
page.content: The area covered by the grid contains great physical contrasts. Peek Hill and Sharpitor display the wild tussocky appearance typical of the western side of Dartmoor - some ferns but little or no heather. The southern slopes are covered by forestry commission woodlands sweeping down to Burrator reservoir. The northern slopes carry on them the Yelverton-princetown road (B3212), from which both the disused railway and the bronze age hut circles near Leeden Tor can be seen. Walkhampton Church is quite separate fom the village but dominates it from its hill. Walkhampton lies in a little saucer, separated from the Walkham valley by a miniature gorge. The Walkham valley is deep and remote, with very narrow lanes and patches of mossy, rock strewn woods.
